title: Protocol for the production and purification of an i-Motif-specific nanobody
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Preparing iMbody plasmid
Timing: 2 days
This section describes the initial steps for propagating and purifying the iMbody plasmid received from Addgene.
Propagation and purification of the plasmid.
Upon receiving the bacterial stab from Addgene, streak the bacteria on a LB-kanamycin agar plate and grow overnight (16–24 h) at 37°C while the plates are upside down to avoid condensation on the culture.
Note: The Addgene stab culture can be stored at 4°C for up to two weeks.
Select five colonies to inoculate five separate 5 mL LB-kanamycin cultures and grow overnight (16–24 h) at 37°C while shaking at 230 revolutions per minute (RPM).
Purify the plasmids using a miniprep kit and store at −20°C.
Making a glycerol stock
Timing: 4 days
This section encompasses steps for transforming competent E. coli cells with pSANG10-3F-iMbody plasmids and creating a glycerol stock of iMbody. The glycerol stock serves as a starting point for subsequent steps in the protocol.
Note: The precise timing is contingent upon the sequencing result that verifies the sequence of iMbody.
Transforming BL21(DE3) competent E. coli cells with pSANG10-3F-iMbody plasmids prepared in Step 1.
Note: The iMbody gene is controlled by a T7 promoter within the pSANG10-3F plasmid. BL21(DE3) cells are highly suitable for T7 expression, although other bacterial strains compatible with T7 expression may also be considered. However, optimizing the expression conditions may be necessary for other strains.
Add 50 ng of each purified plasmid to 25 μL of competent cells separately, and gently mix by flicking the tubes.
Incubate on ice for 30 min.
Perform a heat shock by incubating the tubes at 42°C for 30 s.
Incubate on ice for 5 min.

Add 250 μL LB broth (without kanamycin) to each tube and incubate at 37°C while shaking at 230 RPM for 1 h.
Spread each mixture on a prewarmed LB-kanamycin agar plate, let the plates air-dry on the bench and then grow overnight (16–24 h) at 37°C while the plates are upside down to avoid condensation on the culture.
Note: Perform b-f for 25 μL untransformed competent cells as a control. If colonies are observed on the control plates, then repeat Step 2 using a fresh LB-kanamycin agar plate and make sure the concentration of kanamycin is correct.
Making an iMbody overnight culture.
Using sterile pipette tips, pick one colony from each transformed BL21 plate (five plates in total) to inoculate five separate 10 mL LB-kanamycin cultures and grow overnight (16–24 h) at 37°C while shaking at 230 RPM.
Make a glycerol stock for each transformation by adding 250 μL glycerol to 1 mL overnight culture in a cryovial tube. Mix thoroughly and store at −80°C.
Purify the plasmids from remaining 9 mL overnight culture for each transformation using a miniprep kit and store at −20°C.
For each transformation, verify the sequence of iMbody by sequencing utilizing T7 promoter forward and T7 terminal reverse primers.
Proceed to Step 4 if the iMbody sequence is confirmed by the sequencing results; otherwise, discard unverified minipreps and repeat Steps 2 and 3. Refer to problem 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1] in the troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] section if the issue persists.
Production of iMbody
Timing: 3 days
This section outlines the process for iMbody expression using a verified glycerol stock, with a focus on a 1-L culture. The protocol can be adapted by adjusting reagent quantities for larger cultures.
iMbody expression.

Use a sterile pipette tip to get some bacteria from a verified iMbody glycerol stock and inoculate 50 mL of LB-kanamycin broth and grow overnight (16–24 h) at 37°C while shaking at 230 RPM.
Inoculate 990 mL of LB-kanamycin broth with 10 mL of the overnight culture in a 2-L Erlenmeyer flask.
Grow at 37°C while shaking at 230 RPM. Measure the optical density at 600 nm (OD600nm) initially after 1 h, and then every 10 min thereafter.
When OD600nm reaches to ∼ 0.4–0.5, induce the expression of iMbody by adding 1 mL of 1 M IPTG (final concentration of IPTG in the culture is 1 mM).
Continue growing at 30°C while shaking at 230 RPM for 24 h.
Note: Reducing the temperature from 37°C to 30°C decreases the likelihood of iMbody aggregation in the culture.
Next day, reinduce the expression of iMbody by adding 0.5 mL of 1 M IPTG.
Continue growing at 30°C while shaking at 230 RPM for another 24 h.
Divide the culture over 3 × 500 mL polypropylene bottles and centrifuge at 10,000 × g for 30 min at 4°C.
Filter the supernatant using a vacuum filter system and a 0.22-μm vacuum filter unit. Discard the pellets.
Note: The filtered supernatant can be stored at 4°C for up to one week before purification.
Purification of iMbody
Timing: 1 day
This section provides instructions for the His-tag purification of iMbody and the subsequent concentration of the purified sample.
Capturing His-tagged iMbody using Ni-NTA agarose resins.
Shake the Ni-NTA agarose resins container to mix it well.
Transfer 0.5 mL resins to a 15 mL tube.
Wash the resins twice with 10 mL DPBS.
Resuspend the resin pellet in 1 mL of DPBS and add it to the filtered supernatant.

Incubate for 1 h at 4°C on a roller at 40 RPM .
Running the sample through a gravity column.
Prepare a gravity-flow chromatography column by running two column volume (CV) ddH2O and one CV DPBS through the column.
Flow the supernatant-Ni-NTA resins mixture through the column.
Collect the flow-through and store it at 4°C until running an SDS-PAGE gel.
Close the gravity-flow column and incubate the resins with 30 mL of NPI-20 buffer in the column for 10 min.
Open the column and collect the NPI-20 and add it to the flow-through.
Elution of iMbody.
Close the gravity-flow column and incubate the resins with 5 mL of NPI-500 buffer in the column for 5 min.
Collect the eluted iMbody.
Measure the absorbance at 280 nm (A280nm).
Continue with elution in 5 mL fractions until the A280nm value drops below 0.02. Typically, around five fractions are sufficient to elute all the bound iMbody from 1 L of supernatant.
Combine all fractions in a 50 mL tube, measure the A280nm and keep the tube on ice.
Regenerating the Ni-NTA agarose resins.
Close the gravity-flow column and incubate the resins with 20 mL of NPI-500 buffer in the column for 20 min.
Collect the NPI-500 buffer and dispose of it according to toxic material handling guidelines.
Incubate the resins with 30 mL of 0.5 M NaOH for 30 min in the gravity-column.
Flow-through the NaOH solution and wash the resins with 1 CV ddH2O.
Close the gravity-flow column and collect the resins using 10 mL of 20% ethanol.
Note: Regenerated Ni-NTA agarose resins appear bluish. Use regenerated resins only for purifying His-tagged iMbody. The resin can be stored at 4°C for several months.
Rinse the gravity-flow column using ddH2O.
Buffer exchange and concentration of purified iMbody.

Equilibrate an Amicon ultra-15 centrifugal filter unit (10 kDa cutoff) using 10 mL of DBPS supplemented with 10% glycerol (DPBS-glycerol).
Add 5 mL DPBS-glycerol to the Amicon tube, top it up with 10 mL of eluted iMbody sample, and centrifuge at 3000 × g and 4°C for 7 min.
Collect the flow-through, top up with more iMbody sample, and repeat the process until no iMbody sample remains.
Top up the remaining iMbody sample in the Amicon tube with DPBS-glycerol and centrifuge at 3000 × g and 4°C for 7 min.
Repeat Step 9-d until 50 mL of flow-through is achieved, ensuring the exchange of NPI-500 buffer with DPBS-glycerol.
Continue the centrifugation until the upper chamber of the Amicon tube contains between 0.5 mL to 1 mL of concentrated sample.
Equilibrate two Costar Spin-X centrifuge tubes with DPBS-glycerol.
Transfer the concentrated iMbody sample to Costar Spin-X centrifuge tubes and centrifuge for 1 min at 10000 × g and 4°C.
Measure A280nm and determine the concentration of iMbody using physical parameters calculated by ExPASy8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8] (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]) and the following formulas:

Running an SDS-PAGE to check the purity of purified iMbody.
Add 2 μg iMbody, 4 μL NuPAGE LDS sample buffer, 2 μL NuPAGE sample reducing agent and up to 16 μL molecular biology grade water into a tube.
Heat the sample at 95°C for 5 min.
Load the sample on a NuPAGE 4%–12% Bis-Tris mini protein gel.
Load 7 μL prestained protein ladder in a separate well.
Perform electrophoresis at 200 V using MES-SDS running buffer for 30 min or until well-separated ladder bands appear on the gel.
Rinse the gel using ddH2O.
Stain the gel using 15 mL EZBlue gel staining reagent for 1 h at room temperature (∼ 22°C) with gentle orbital shaking.
Destain extensively using ddH2O overnight (16–24 h) or until the blue background is faded at room temperature (∼ 22°C) with gentle orbital shaking.
A blue band corresponding to 17.3 kDa (between 15 and 25 kDa) appears (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]). See problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3] in troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] section if sample contains impurities.

Figure 2. SDS-PAGE result for purified iMbody-6×His-3×FLAG (17.3 kDa)
Lane 1: iMbody purified from periplasm contains impurities.
Lane 2: iMbody purified from supernatant.
In each lane, 2 μg of purified sample was loaded.
After confirming the purity of iMbody through SDS-PAGE, dispense the purified iMbody sample into 50 μL aliquots and store them at −80°C.
Note: Purified samples stored at −80°C remain stable for a minimum of one year, but it's advisable to prevent frequent freeze-thaw cycles. Upon thawing an aliquot, it should be filtered using a Costar Spin-X centrifuge tube, and the concentration should be determined following the instructions in Step 9. Purified samples can be stored in a refrigerator (2°C–8°C) for up to one week. We strongly recommend filtering the sample and assessing the iMbody concentration before each use.
Performing ELISA using iMbody

Timing: 2 days
This section delineates the ELISA procedure utilizing iMbody for the characterization of a putative iM-forming oligonucleotide. By incorporating the positive and negative controls specified in this protocol, this method can serve as a complement to other techniques, such as circular dichroism spectroscopy, used in the characterization of iM-forming oligonucleotides.
Preparing DNA oligonucleotides.
Order 5′ Biotin-TEG conjugated DNA oligonucleotides as lyophilized samples.
Note: Oligonucleotides used in this protocol are listed in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2].
Briefly centrifuge the tube before opening it to avoid losing samples that might be attached to the cap.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3145_5.csv
All oligonucleotides are 5′-Biotin-TEG conjugated.
Reconstitute the oligonucleotide in nuclease-free water to make a 100 μM stock solution. This solution can then be further diluted using a preferred buffer.
Vortex thoroughly. If it is difficult to resuspend, heat the tube at 55°C for 10 min followed by vortexing and centrifugation.
Measure the concentration and purity of the stock solution. A ratio above 1.8 for Abs260nm/Abs280nm and Abs260nm/Abs230nm is generally considered as pure for DNA samples.
The stock solution of a DNA oligonucleotide can be stored at −80°C for at least 2 years.
Annealing DNA oligonucleotides.
Dilute an iM-forming oligonucleotide in 200 mM Tris-HCl pH 6 to a final concentration of 70 nM. Prepare a 60 μL DNA solution for each well and ensure at least duplicates for each condition.
Anneal the oligonucleotide by heating at 95°C for 10 min followed by slowly cooling down to room temperature (∼ 22°C), and then keep it at 4°C overnight (16–24 h).
Note: Control oligonucleotides should be diluted and annealed in appropriate buffers. For example, we dilute and anneal G-quadruplexes in 200 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.2 supplemented with 100 mM KCl and double-stranded DNA in IDT nuclease-free duplex buffer.
Immobilizing DNA oligonucleotides on a plate.

Coat a 96-well Nunc MaxiSorp plate by adding 50 μL per well of 50 μg/mL NeutrAvidin diluted in DPBS.
Shake the plate gently, seal it with a SealPlate film, and incubate overnight (16–24 h) at 4°C.
Aspirate the contents and wash one time with DPBS (250 μL per well). After washing, turn the plate upside down and gently tap on absorbent paper to eliminate any extra liquid.
Block the plate by adding 200 μL per well of DPBS supplemented with 2% BSA and 0.1% Tween 20 for 2 h at room temperature (∼ 22°C) while shaking at 300 RPM on a plate shaker or overnight (16–24 h) at 4°C.
Aspirate the blocking buffer and wash one time with 200 mM Tris-HCl pH 6 or appropriate buffers for the control oligonucleotides (250 μL per well). After washing, turn the plate upside down and gently tap on absorbent paper to eliminate any extra liquid.
Add 60 μL of annealed DNA samples to each well and incubate at room temperature (∼22°C) for 1 h while shaking at 300 RPM on a plate shaker.
Aspirate the contents and wash one time with DPBS (250 μL per well). After washing, turn the plate upside down and gently tap on absorbent paper to eliminate any extra liquid.
Adding iMbody.
Thaw the required volume of iMbody, based on the concentration determined after His-tag purification and the number of samples in the planned ELISA experiment.
Filter using a Costar Spin-X centrifuge tube and determine the concentration again, following the instructions in Step 9.
Note: The new concentration might be slightly different due to aggregation and loss of the purified iMbody caused by freeze-thawing.

Make a serial dilution of iMbody starting from 10 nM to 19.5 pM in DPBS supplemented with 5% BSA, 0.1% Tween 20 and 100 μg/mL salmon sperm DNA. Incubate at room temperature (∼22°C) for 15 min.
Add 60 μL of serially diluted iMbody per well and incubate at room temperature (∼22°C) for 45 min while shaking at 300 RPM on a plate shaker.
Aspirate the contents and wash three times with DPBS supplemented with 0.1% Tween 20 and once with DPBS (250 μL per well). After each washing, turn the plate upside down and gently tap on absorbent paper to eliminate any extra liquid.
Adding secondary antibody.
Dilute the HRP-conjugated anti-FLAG antibody 1:15000 in DPBS supplemented with 2% BSA, 0.1% Tween 20. Incubate at room temperature (∼22°C) for 15 min.
Add 50 μL diluted HRP-conjugated anti-FLAG antibody per well and incubate at room temperature (∼22°C) for 45 min while shaking at 300 RPM on a plate shaker.
Aspirate the contents and wash twice with DPBS supplemented with 0.1% Tween 20 and once with DPBS (250 μL per well). After each washing, turn the plate upside down and gently tap on absorbent paper to eliminate any extra liquid.
Developing the enzymatic reaction.
Add 50 μL of TMB substrate solution to each well and incubate at room temperature (∼22°C) with occasional gentle shaking until a dark blue color develops for the highest concentration of iMbody.
Stop the reaction by adding 50 μL of 0.5 M HCl per well.
Read the absorbance at 450 nm using a UV-vis plate reader within 10 min of adding HCl.
Make the graph in GraphPad Prism (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A). See problem 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5] in troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] section if significant cross-reactivity with negative controls is observed.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3145-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Using iMbody in ELISA

(A) ELISA represents the binding of 10 nM iMbody to four different iM-forming oligonucleotides and a range of controls.
(B) ELISA shows the binding of serially diluted iMbody to iM-Myc oligonucleotide, which was annealed in the presence of various concentrations of SWNT-COOH or DMF (used to disperse SWNT-COOH). The plotted values represent the mean ± standard error of two replicates, obtained through a serial dilution of iMbody starting from 10 nM to 19.5 pM. Curve fitting was conducted using the "One site - Specific binding" equation in GraphPad Prism. The oligonucleotide sequences are provided in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2].
Note: To explore potential competition between a small molecule and iMbody, the iM-forming oligonucleotide should be annealed in the presence of the small molecule. For instance, we anneal iM-Myc oligonucleotide with final concentrations of 5, 10, and 20 μg/mL SWNT-COOH (dispersed in DMF), which has been demonstrated to recognize iMs.19[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib19],20[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib20] Additionally, we include a control sample containing only DMF (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B). The rest of the protocol remains unchanged as described above.
Performing immunostaining using iMbody
Timing: 4 days
This section provides a detailed procedure for visualizing iMs in HeLa cells using iMbody. This includes preparing the coverslips for the cell culture, seeding HeLa cells, and performing fixation and permeabilization to prepare them for immunostaining. The subsequent steps involve adding iMbody and appropriate secondary and tertiary antibodies, followed by mounting the coverslips on slides. Finally, the section outlines the microscopy and image acquisition process and provides guidance on post-imaging processing to visualize iMs within the cells.
Note: The precise timing varies depending on the cell growth rate. The mentioned timing starts from the seeding day of HeLa cells.
Preparing coverslips.
Acid treat glass coverslips (#1.5) by submerging them in 1 M HCl and incubating at room temperature (∼22°C) at least for 3 h.

Rinse the coverslips three times using ddH2O, followed by three rinses with pure ethanol.
Air dry the coverslips in a biosafety cabinet.
Place each coverslip into an individual well of a 12-well plate containing 1 mL of 0.001% poly-L-lysine solution diluted in molecular biology grade water. Allow them to incubate at room temperature (∼22°C) for 20 min.
Aspirate the poly-L-lysine solution. Rinse with 1 mL molecular biology grade water per well and air dry the coverslip in a biosafety cabinet.
Sterilize under the UV light in a biosafety cabinet for at least 1 h.
Seeding HeLa cells.
Note: Below is the protocol for the immunostaining of HeLa cells. The ideal iMbody concentration for immunostaining other cells might vary and should be established through a preliminary pilot experiment involving a serial dilution on synchronized cells.
Grow HeLa cells in a T75 cell culture flask using DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS and 1% penicillin-streptomycin (complete media) until they reach 70%–80% confluency.
Rinse the cells twice with 15 mL of warm (∼37°C) DPBS.
Add 4 mL warm (∼37°C) trypsin-EDTA to the flask and incubate at 37°C for 5 min or until all cells are detached.
Add 8 mL warm (∼37°C) complete media to the flask to deactivate trypsin and collect the cells into a 15 mL tube.
Centrifuge for 1 min at 500 × g at room temperature (∼22°C).
Discard the supernatant and gently resuspend the cells with up to 1 mL complete media.
Count the number of cells using a hemocytometer. Keep the tube containing the remaining cells in a 37°C water bath.
Seed 1 × 104 cells resuspended in 1 mL complete media in each well that contains poly-L-lysine coated coverslip.

Incubate the cells at 37°C and 5% CO2 until they reach 70%–80% confluency, which may take 1–2 days after seeding 1 × 104 cells per well.
Fixation and permeabilization of the cells.
Pre-fix the cells by adding 1 mL of 1% formaldehyde diluted in DPBS directly to the well containing media and incubating for 2 min at room temperature (∼22°C).
Critical: Formaldehyde is toxic. Work in a fume hood and wear suitable personal protective equipment while diluting 16% formaldehyde to 1% using DPBS. Avoid skin contact and inhalation. Prepare fresh 1% formaldehyde for each immunostaining.
Aspirate the content and rinse the cells once with 1 mL ice-cold DPBS per well.
Fix the cells by adding 1 mL 1% formaldehyde in each well and incubating for 15 min at 4°C without shaking.
Rinse the cells twice with 1 mL ice-cold DPBS per well.
Permeabilize the cells by adding 1 mL of ice-cold 0.1% Triton X-100 diluted in DPBS in each well and incubating for 15 min at 4°C without shaking.
Rinse the cells twice with 1 mL ice-cold DPBS per well.
Block the coverslip and cells with 1 mL DPBS supplemented with 2% BSA, 1% skim milk, 0.1% Tween 20 and 0.01% Triton X (blocking buffer) for 3 h at 4°C.
Adding iMbody.
Thaw the required volume of iMbody, based on the concentration determined after His-tag purification and the number of samples planned for the immunostaining experiment.
Filter using a Costar Spin-X centrifuge tube and determine the concentration again, following the instructions in Step 9.
Note: The new concentration might be slightly different due to aggregation and loss of the purified iMbody caused by freeze-thawing.
Prepare a serial dilution of iMbody ranging from 2 μM to 500 nM in the blocking buffer. For each well, 350 μL is required.

Note: Always include control wells including no iMbody and no secondary antibody.
Aspirate the blocking buffer and dispense 350 μL per well of a serially diluted iMbody. Incubate overnight (16–20 h) at 4°C.
Next day, perform four washes on the cells using 1 mL of ice-cold DPBS supplemented with 0.1% Tween 20 per well. Each wash should last for 5 min and involve gentle shaking at 200 RPM on a plate shaker.
Rinse the cells with 1 mL per well of ice-cold DPBS.
Adding secondary antibody.
Dispense 350 μL of rabbit anti-FLAG antibody (1:600 dilution) per well, after diluting in the blocking buffer.
Incubate at room temperature (∼22°C) for 30 min while shaking at 200 RPM on a plate shaker.
Perform two washes on the cells using 1 mL of ice-cold DPBS supplemented with 0.1% Tween 20 per well. Each wash should last for 5 min and involve shaking at 200 RPM on a plate shaker.
Rinse the cells with 1 mL per well of ice-cold DPBS.
Adding tertiary antibody and phalloidin.
Dispense 350 μL of Alexa Fluor 488-conjugated anti-rabbit (1:400 dilution) and Alexa Fluor 555-conjugated phalloidin (1:20 dilution) per well, after diluting in the blocking buffer.
Cover the plate with aluminum foil and incubate at room temperature (∼22°C) for 30 min while shaking at 200 RPM on a plate shaker.
Perform two washes on the cells using 1 mL of ice-cold DPBS supplemented with 0.1% Tween 20 per well. Each wash should last for 5 min and involve shaking at 200 RPM on a plate shaker.
Rinse the cells twice with 1 mL per well of molecular biology grade water.
Mounting the coverslips.

Carefully remove the coverslip from the plate and place it onto a paper towel, such as a Kimwipe, allowing it to air dry within a biosafety cabinet. Ensure that the side of the coverslip with attached cells does not come into contact with the paper towel.
Dispense 15 μL of ProLong Gold antifade reagent with DAPI onto the center of a slide.
Mount the coverslip onto the slide in a way that the side of the coverslip with attached cells faces downward and makes contact with the mounting reagent.
Place the slides within a cassette and store them in a dark location at room temperature (∼22°C) overnight (16–24 h).
Seal the edge of the coverslip with nail polish and transfer the slides to 4°C protected from light for a long-term storage. Staining will last for a few weeks.
Note: Sealing is not required if the image acquisition takes place within one week after the staining process.
Microscopy and image acquisition.
Acquire images on a Leica TCS SP8 confocal microscope using a 63×/1.40 oil (HC PL APO CS2) objective or a similar confocal microscope with the following settings:
Use a 405 nm laser (laser power 3%) to excite and image DAPI (nucleus).
Use a 488 nm laser (laser power 50%) to excite and image Alexa Fluor 488 (iMs).
Use a 561 nm laser (laser power 5%) to excite and image Alexa Fluor 555 (actin filaments).
Use HyD detector with counting mode.
Speed 400 Hz.
Pinhole 1 airy unit.
Sequential frame scanning.
Frame accumulation 3.
Identify the cell boundary using actin filaments and zoom in when investigating iMs within an individual cell.
Note: Maintain a consistent frame size when examining the formation of iMs under various treatment conditions.

Identify the starting and ending points of a nucleus, then employ the “system optimized” to determine the required number of z-stacks and intervals.
Post-imaging processing.
Note: The following procedure outlines the generation of Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4] in this paper. Post-imaging processing is contingent upon the experimental settings and the research questions being addressed by the experiment.
Open the microscopy image in Fiji with following setting:

Figure 4. Visualization of i-Motifs in the nuclei of HeLa cells
(A) Confocal images of HeLa cells stained with different concentrations of iMbody. Maximum intensity projection of images is displayed. Nuclei are shown in blue (stained with DAPI), actin filaments (F-actin) are shown in red (stained with Alexa Fluor 555 phalloidin), and i-Motifs are shown in green (stained with FLAG-tagged iMbody, rabbit anti-FLAG secondary antibodies, and Alexa Fluor 488 anti-rabbit tertiary antibodies). The green channel in all images is smoothed using FIJI, and maximum and minimum displayed values are set to 100 and 70, respectively.
(B) Confocal images of a HeLa cell stained with 1 μM of iMbody. Six frames of a z-stack are displayed. i-Motifs are present in N2, N3 and N4 images. The green channel is smoothed using FIJI, and maximum and minimum displayed values are set to 100 and 70, respectively. The scale bars represent 10 μm. Images were captured using a Leica TCS SP8 confocal microscope.
View stack with: Hyperstack.
Dataset: Open files individually.
Color options: Colorized, Autoscale.
Split into separate windows: Split channels.
Select a captured image.
Adjust the Brightness/Contrast:
Navigate to the brightest image in blue (nucleus) and red (F-actin) channels and choose “Auto” in the B&C pop up.

Navigate to the brightest image in the green (iMs) channel and choose the “Auto” option in the B&C pop-up. Continue refining the “Minimum” and “Maximum” settings until distinct foci become visible and there is no background interference.
Note: Maintain a consistent “Minimum” and “Maximum” setting in the green channel (iMs) for different concentrations of iMbody used in the immunostaining, as well as when examining the impact of various treatments or conditions on the iM formation.
Smooth the channels (optional).
Merge the channels and create a composite while keeping the source images.
